awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity to Recruit and Prepare High-Quality Secondary STEM Educators in Kentucky
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to serve the national need for highly qualified biology and mathematics teachers in secondary schools. In particular, the project will address the secondary STEM teacher shortage in rural Kentucky. This will be accomplished by bringing together STEM faculty and Education faculty to collaborate on improving STEM courses and aligning course content with state teacher certification standards. Additionally, the project will collect evidence from college students about their interests in teaching careers and use this information to improve recruitment of future secondary STEM teachers. Further, the project will explore the feasibility of building a new Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) program that could provide a graduate education pathway to secondary STEM teaching careers.

This Capacity Building project at Lindsey Wilson College includes partnerships with Somerset Community College and two high-need local school districts – Russell County Schools and Adair County Schools – that will lay the groundwork for a future Noyce Track 1: Scholarships and Stipends proposal. The project goals are to: 1) improve coordination among STEM and Education faculty; 2) collect evidence and develop new strategies to increase enrollment of future secondary STEM teachers; and 3) determine feasibility of a new Master of Arts in STEM Teaching graduate program. To accomplish these goals, the campus will establish a new STEM Education Curriculum Committee to build key bridges between STEM and Education faculty. STEM faculty will be engaged in taking the PRAXIS subject assessments for teachers as a novel approach to guide authentic revision of 36 STEM content courses to produce highly qualified future secondary STEM teachers for the region. Additionally, the project will collect evidence from students to inform and improve materials to recruit undergraduate STEM majors, local community college transfer students, and local high school students to secondary STEM teaching careers. The project will translate recruitment materials into Spanish and conduct outreach specifically to reach Hispanic and Latino students, who are currently underrepresented in the teacher workforce compared to secondary student populations in the region. An experienced, external consultant will be contracted to analyze the feasibility of developing a Master of Arts in Teaching program that could enable entry to STEM teaching careers at the graduate level, in addition to efforts to attract future STEM teachers from undergraduate student populations. Project evaluation will be led by an Advisory Committee composed of stakeholders from the campus, the local school districts, and the partner community college. In addition to building capacity to recruit new secondary STEM educators in the region, the project will produce insights into how STEM and Education faculty can collaborate to revise undergraduate STEM curricula such that they align with state certification standards and better prepare highly effective secondary STEM teachers. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the retention and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project proposed to address multiple institutional needs through a Capacity Building project entitled “Building Together: Partners Creating Strong STEM Educators”  (Building Together). Addressing these needs strengthened faculty collaboration between programs, identified specific recruitment and retention strategies that targeted Hispanic and other underserved groups to enter STEM education fields, to build stronger partnerships and create new pipelines from high school and area community colleges directly to Lindsey Wilson College. The project objectives and measures were as follows: (1) to improve coordination among STEM and education faculty, ensuring STEM education curricula reflect current state standards; measured with pre/post surveys with faculty. Surveys were then analyzed by the advisory committee. Curriculum maps were created pre/post curriculum work to demonstrate increased alignment and work completed for this portion of the grant, along with recorded meeting minutes. (2) to implement new strategies and partnerships that will increase enrollment of STEM educators. To measure this, an inventory of marketing outputs and distribution has been created along with a Noyce webpage. Meeting minutes, communications, and any formal communication with partners has been created and stored; and (3) to determine whether a new Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) program in STEM education is needed and feasible. The Advisory Council received and reviewed the Needs Assessment report from the Blackmoor Group, LLC.. The PI presented the final report to the Vice President of Academic Affairs and will present it to the Education Advisory Committee in the fall, 2023 to determine program viability. The expected long-term outcome is increased enrollment in Mathematics and Biology Education programs, increased graduation rates including first-generation, low socio-economic, Hispanic, women and other underserved groups, as well as a decrease in teacher shortages in the mathematics and biology field, through this capacity building track.

The created project teams were a collaboration of area partners, STEM education experts and STEM faculty, along with recruitment, retention, and promotion experts. The potential for the formation of the Advisory Council and Curriculum Committees to advance knowledge and understanding within its own field or across different fields is high. The council/ committee have enabled LWC to collaborate both internally and externally at levels that had not been possible prior to grant approval. They have also provided education and STEM faculty support from administration, partnering districts, the community college, and the state department to create and/or strengthen partnerships in ways that are normally difficult for small, rural, private institutions with limited faculty. These partnerships will benefit society by affording LWC opportunities to continue to collaboratively create new programs that will allow easier access for underrepresented students and to build essential pipelines for critical teacher shortage areas in STEM fields. Presenting outcomes at the 2023 Noyce Summit, the PI discussed findings with representatives from small institutions and their feedback was impactful, as each had specific but similar take-aways. They were interested in establishing a Teaching Career Pathway at their local high-schools and intrigued with the idea of a Master of Teaching Program at their institution. The PI and the participants discussed findings at length, along with the benefits and challenges that the committees faced in order for summit attendees to take findings back to their home institution and utilize these findings in their own grant applications or programs.

The Public Relations collaborative campaign and recruitment efforts with the LWC Admissions department, First Year Experience staff and local school district partners provided new opportunities for the LWC Education programs to explore creative, original, or potentially transformative recruitment efforts for specific academic programs where few existed. This collaboration, made possible by grant funding, was transformative in its empowerment of the PR subcommittee and PR staff to create materials that targeted demographics of underrepresented populations. Digital ads, geofencing, pre-roll, rack cards and other PR materials were formerly unknown to the subcommittee and the cost-analysis and resulting data show the marketing campaign was extremely effective for capturing the attention of the target audience.

A significant increase in collaboration, positive relationships and increased pedagogical understanding were created because of this grant opportunity. Bi-weekly mapping and planning meetings occurred with robust cross-curricular conversations, which increased the understanding of STEM and education requirements and needs. Pedagogical training sessions, focusing on research-based strategies that include Diversity, Inclusion, Equity and Belonging, increased accessibility for underrepresented groups, and LWC education and STEM faculty took advantage of this opportunity to learn new pedagogical strategies including Transparent Design of Assignments, Authentic Assignments, Collaborative Learning, and Flipped Classrooms to implement to make  coursework more accessible to all students.

 The positive outcomes attributed to this “Building Together” grant, has allowed Lindsey Wilson College to grow its Secondary Mathematics and Biology Education programs population and the work started here will continue. This work has developed the potential of these programs to build enough capacity to qualify to apply for a Track I grant in the future.


 


Last Modified: 07/07/2023
Modified by: Jennifer A Neal
